title: Tutorials
text:
Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari






Cellpose


Transfer learning



Tutorial for fine-tuning the “nuclei” model from cellpose to new data.





Fernando Cervantes






No matching items

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
text:
Follow the instructions to install napari from its official website.









Important



If you installed napari using conda, activate that same environment before installing the Active Learning plugin.


Install the plugin adding [cellpose] to the command so all dependencies required for this tutorial are available.
python -m pip install "napari-activelearning[cellpose]"

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 1.1. Load a sample image
text:
1.1. Load a sample image
You can use the cells 3D image sample from napari’s built-in samples.
File > Open Sample > napari builtins > Cells (3D+2Ch)

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 1.2. Add the Image Groups Manager widget to napari’s window
text:
1.2. Add the Image Groups Manager widget to napari’s window
The Image groups manager can be found under the Active Learning plugin in napari’s plugins menu.
Plugins > Active Learning > Image groups manager

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 1.3. Create an Image Group containing nuclei and membrane layers
text:
1.3. Create an Image Group containing nuclei and membrane layers

Select the nuclei and membrane layer
Click the New Image Group button on the Image Groups Manager widget

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 1.4. Edit the image group properties
text:
1.4. Edit the image group properties



Select the newly created image group, it will appear as “images” in the Image groups manager widget.
Click the Edit group properties checkbox.
Make sure that Axes order is “CZYX”, otherwise, you can edit it and press Enter to update the axes names.

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 2.1. Add the Acquisition function configuration widget to napari’s window
text:
2.1. Add the Acquisition function configuration widget to napari’s window
The Acquisition function configuration is under the Active Learning plugin in napari’s plugins menu.
Plugins > Active Learning > Acquisition function configuration






Tip



All Active Learning widgets can be un-docked from their current place and re-docked into other more convenient location within napari’s window, or even as tabs, as illustrated in this tutorial.

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 2.2. Define sampling configuration
text:
2.2. Define sampling configuration



Make sure “Input axes” are set to “ZYX”







Note



This specifies that the samples will be taken from those axes.



Change the “Model axes” to “CYX”







Note



And this specifies that sample’s axes will be permuted to match the “Model axes” order.

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 2.3. Set the size of the sampling patch
text:
2.3. Set the size of the sampling patch













Click the “Edit patch size” checkbox
Change the patch size of “X” and “Y” to 256, and the “Z” axis to 1.







Note



This directs the Active Learning plugin to sample at random patches of size \(256\times256\) pixels, and \(1\) slice of depth.

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 2.4. Define the maximum number of samples to extract
text:
2.4. Define the maximum number of samples to extract













Set the “Maximum samples” to \(4\) and press Enter







Note



This tells the Active Learning plugin to process at most four samples at random from the whole image.

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 2.5. Configure the segmentation method
text:
2.5. Configure the segmentation method



Use the “Model” dropdown list to select the cellpose method
Click the “Advanced segmentation parameters” checkbox
Change the “Channel axis” to \(0\)







Note



This makes cellpose to use the first axis as “Color” channel.



Change the second channel to \(1\) (the right spin box in the “channels” row)







Note



This tells cellpose to segment the first channel (\(0\)) and use the second channel (\(1\)) as help channel.



Choose the “nuclei” model from the dropdown list

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 2.6. Execute the segmentation method on all image groups
text:
2.6. Execute the segmentation method on all image groups



Click the “Run on all image groups” button







Note



To execute the segmentation only on specific image groups, select the desired image groups in the Image groups manager widget and use the “Run on selected image groups” button instead.

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 2.7. Inspect the segmentation layer
text:
2.7. Inspect the segmentation layer






Note



Because the input image is 3D, you might have to slide the Z index at the bottom of napari’s window to look at the samples that have been segmented.

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 3.1. Create a mask to restrict the sampling space
text:
3.1. Create a mask to restrict the sampling space



Switch to the Image groups manager tab
Click the “Edit mask properties” checkbox
Set the mask scale to \(256\) for the “X” and “Y” axes, and a scale of \(1\) for the “Z” axis
Click the “Create mask” button







Note



This creates a low-resolution mask where each of its pixels corresponds to a \(256\times256\) pixels region in the input image. Because the mask is low-resolution, it uses less space in memory and disk.

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 3.2. Specify the samplable regions
text:
3.2. Specify the samplable regions

Draw a mask that covers slices \(27\) to \(30\) in the “Z” axis.







Note



Move the slider at the bottom of napari’s window to navigate between slices in the “Z” axis.

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 3.3. Execute the segmentation process on the masked regions
text:
3.3. Execute the segmentation process on the masked regions



Go back to the Acquisition function configuration widget
Click the “Run on all image groups” button again







Note



Because the image group has a defined mask, samples will be extracted at random inside those defined regions only.

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 3.4. Inspect the masked segmentation output
text: 3.4. Inspect the masked segmentation output

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 4.1. Add the Label groups manager widget to napari’s window
text:
4.1. Add the Label groups manager widget to napari’s window
You can find the Label groups manager under the Active Learning plugin in napari’s plugins menu.
Plugins > Active Learning > Label groups manager

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 4.2. Select a segmented patch to edit
text:
4.2. Select a segmented patch to edit

Double click on any segmented patch in the viewer (e.g. on slice \(27\))







Note



This creates a new editable “Labels edit” layer with a copy of the selected patch.

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 4.3. Use napari’s layer controls to make changes on the objects of the current patch
text: 4.3. Use napari’s layer controls to make changes on the objects of the current patch

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 4.4. Commit changes to the labels layer
text:
4.4. Commit changes to the labels layer

Once you have finished editing the labels, click the “Commit changes” button on the Label groups manager

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 4.5. Navigate between segmented patches
text:
4.5. Navigate between segmented patches



Expand the second group of labels
Double-click on any of the nested items to open it for editing
Use the navigation buttons to move between segmented patches
Continue editing the segmentation in the current patch and commit the changes when finished

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 4.6. Setup fine tuning configuration
text:
4.6. Setup fine tuning configuration



Go to the Acquisition function configuration widget
Click the “Advanced fine tuning parameters” checkbox
Change the “save path” to a location where you want to store the fine tuned model

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 4.6. Setup fine tuning configuration
text:
4.6. Setup fine tuning configuration



Change the “model name” to “nuclei_ft”







Note



Scroll the Advanced fine tuning parameters widget down to show more parameters.



Set the “batch size” to \(3\)
Change the “learning rate” to \(0.0001\)







Note



You can modify other parameters for the training process here, such as the number of training epochs.

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 4.7. Execute the fine tuning process
text:
4.7. Execute the fine tuning process



Click the “Fine tune model” button to run the training process.







Note



Depending on your computer resources (RAM, CPU), this process might take some minutes to complete. If you have a dedicated GPU device, this can take a couple of seconds instead.

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 4.8. Review the fine tuned segmentation
text:
4.8. Review the fine tuned segmentation






Tip



Use the opacity slider to compare how the fine tuned model segments the same objects that were labeled for training.

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 5.1. Create a mask to apply the fine tuned model for inference
text:
5.1. Create a mask to apply the fine tuned model for inference



Switch to the Image groups manager tab
Click the “Edit mask properties” checkbox
Set the mask scale to \(256\) for the “X” and “Y” axes, and a scale of \(1\) for the “Z” axis
Click the “Create mask” button

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 5.2. Specify the samplable regions for inference
text:
5.2. Specify the samplable regions for inference

Draw a mask that covers slices \(31\) to \(34\) in the “Z” axis.

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 5.3. Select the new mask layer to be used for sampling positions
text:
5.3. Select the new mask layer to be used for sampling positions



Scroll down the Image groups manager tree to show the newest mask layer grup (“mask (1)”)
Select the “mask (1)” layer group







Note



The “Group name” column in the groups tree can be resized to show the complete names.



Make sure that “Use as sampling mask” checkbox is checked

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 5.4. Use the fine tuned model for inference in the masked region
text:
5.4. Use the fine tuned model for inference in the masked region



Go back to the Acquisition function configuration widget
Click “Run on all image groups” button again

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 5.5. Inspect the output of the fine tuned model
text:
5.5. Inspect the output of the fine tuned model

Now you have a fine tuned model for nuclei segmentation that has been adapted to this image!







Note



The fine tuned model can be used in Cellpose’s GUI software, their python API package, or any other package that supports pretrained cellpose models.

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 5.6. Segment the newly masked region with the base model
text:
5.6. Segment the newly masked region with the base model



Choose the “nuclei” model again from the dropdown list in the Advanced segmentation parameters section
Click the “Run on all image groups” button again







Note



This will execute the segmentation process with the non-fine-tuned “nuclei” model on the same sampling positions from the last run.

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 5.7. Compare the results of both models
text:
5.7. Compare the results of both models






Tip



Hide all the layers and show only the “nuclei” and “membrane” layers, as well as the “images segmentation [2]” and “images segmentation [3]” layers that correspond to the output of the fine tuned model and base model, respectively.

section: 3.3. Execute the segmentation process on the masked regions
text:
3.3. Execute the segmentation process on the masked regions



Go back to the Acquisition function configuration widget
Click the “Run on all image groups” button again







Note


Because the image group has a defined mask, samples will be extracted at random inside those defined regions only.

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 3.4. Inspect the masked segmentation output
text: 3.4. Inspect the masked segmentation output

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 4.1. Add the Label groups manager widget to napari’s window
text:
4.1. Add the Label groups manager widget to napari’s window
You can find the Label groups manager under the Active Learning plugin in napari’s plugins menu.
Plugins > Active Learning > Label groups manager

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 4.2. Select a segmented patch to edit
text:
4.2. Select a segmented patch to edit

Double click on any segmented patch in the viewer (e.g. on slice \(27\))







Note


This creates a new editable “Labels edit” layer with a copy of the selected patch.

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 4.3. Use napari’s layer controls to make changes on the objects of the current patch
text: 4.3. Use napari’s layer controls to make changes on the objects of the current patch

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 4.4. Commit changes to the labels layer
text:
4.4. Commit changes to the labels layer

Once you have finished editing the labels, click the “Commit changes” button on the Label groups manager

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 4.5. Navigate between segmented patches
text:
4.5. Navigate between segmented patches



Expand the second group of labels
Double-click on any of the nested items to open it for editing
Use the navigation buttons to move between segmented patches
Continue editing the segmentation in the current patch and commit the changes when finished

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 4.6. Setup fine tuning configuration
text:
4.6. Setup fine tuning configuration



Go to the Acquisition function configuration widget
Click the “Advanced fine tuning parameters” checkbox
Change the “save path” to a location where you want to store the fine tuned model

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 4.6. Setup fine tuning configuration
text:
4.6. Setup fine tuning configuration



Change the “model name” to “nuclei_ft”







Note


Scroll the Advanced fine tuning parameters widget down to show more parameters.




Set the “batch size” to \(3\)
Change the “learning rate” to \(0.0001\)







Note


You can modify other parameters for the training process here, such as the number of training epochs.

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 4.7. Execute the fine tuning process
text:
4.7. Execute the fine tuning process



Click the “Fine tune model” button to run the training process.







Note


Depending on your computer resources (RAM, CPU), this process might take some minutes to complete. If you have a dedicated GPU device, this can take a couple of seconds instead.

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 4.8. Review the fine tuned segmentation
text:
4.8. Review the fine tuned segmentation






Tip


Use the opacity slider to compare how the fine tuned model segments the same objects that were labeled for training.

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 5.1. Create a mask to apply the fine tuned model for inference
text:
5.1. Create a mask to apply the fine tuned model for inference



Switch to the Image groups manager tab
Click the “Edit mask properties” checkbox
Set the mask scale to \(256\) for the “X” and “Y” axes, and a scale of \(1\) for the “Z” axis
Click the “Create mask” button

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 5.2. Specify the samplable regions for inference
text:
5.2. Specify the samplable regions for inference

Draw a mask that covers slices \(31\) to \(34\) in the “Z” axis.

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 5.3. Select the new mask layer to be used for sampling positions
text:
5.3. Select the new mask layer to be used for sampling positions



Scroll down the Image groups manager tree to show the newest mask layer grup (“mask (1)”)
Select the “mask (1)” layer group







Note


The “Group name” column in the groups tree can be resized to show the complete names.




Make sure that “Use as sampling mask” checkbox is checked

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 5.4. Use the fine tuned model for inference in the masked region
text:
5.4. Use the fine tuned model for inference in the masked region



Go back to the Acquisition function configuration widget
Click “Run on all image groups” button again

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 5.5. Inspect the output of the fine tuned model
text:
5.5. Inspect the output of the fine tuned model

Now you have a fine tuned model for nuclei segmentation that has been adapted to this image!







Note


The fine tuned model can be used in Cellpose’s GUI software, their python API package, or any other package that supports pretrained cellpose models.

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 5.6. Segment the newly masked region with the base model
text:
5.6. Segment the newly masked region with the base model



Choose the “nuclei” model again from the dropdown list in the Advanced segmentation parameters section
Click the “Run on all image groups” button again







Note


This will execute the segmentation process with the non-fine-tuned “nuclei” model on the same sampling positions from the last run.

title: Tutorial: How to fine tune a Cellpose model with the Active Learning plugin for Napari
section: 5.7. Compare the results of both models
text:
5.7. Compare the results of both models






Tip


Hide all the layers and show only the “nuclei” and “membrane” layers, as well as the “images segmentation [2]” and “images segmentation [3]” layers that correspond to the output of the fine tuned model and base model, respectively.
